name: fin7

procedures: T1005::[FIN7] has collected files and other sensitive information from a compromised network.
T1008::[FIN7]'s Harpy backdoor malware can use DNS as a backup channel for C2 if HTTP fails.
T1021.001::[FIN7] has used RDP to move laterally in victim environments.
T1021.004::[FIN7] has used SSH to move laterally through victim environments.
T1021.005::[FIN7] has used TightVNC to control compromised hosts.
T1027.010::[FIN7] has used fragmented strings, environment variables, standard input (stdin), and native character-replacement functionalities to obfuscate commands.
T1036.004::[FIN7] has created a scheduled task named “AdobeFlashSync” to establish persistence.
T1036.005::[FIN7] has attempted to run Darkside ransomware with the filename sleep.exe.
T1047::[FIN7] has used WMI to install malware on targeted systems.
T1053.005::[FIN7] malware has created scheduled tasks to establish persistence.
T1059.001::[FIN7] used a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieved an additional payload.
T1059.003::[FIN7] used the command prompt to launch commands on the victim’s machine.
T1059.005::[FIN7] used VBS scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.
T1059.007::[FIN7] used JavaScript scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.
T1059::[FIN7] used SQL scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.
T1071.004::[FIN7] has performed C2 using DNS via A, OPT, and TXT records.
T1078::[FIN7] has harvested valid administrative credentials for lateral movement.
T1091::[FIN7] actors have mailed USB drives to potential victims containing malware that downloads and installs various backdoors, including in some cases for ransomware operations.
T1102.002::[FIN7] used legitimate services like Google Docs, Google Scripts, and Pastebin for C2.
T1105::[FIN7] has downloaded additional malware to execute on the victim's machine, including by using a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieves an additional payload.
T1113::[FIN7] captured screenshots and desktop video recordings.
T1125::[FIN7] created a custom video recording capability that could be used to monitor operations in the victim's environment.
T1204.001::[FIN7] has used malicious links to lure victims into downloading malware.
T1204.002::[FIN7] lured victims to double-click on images in the attachments they sent which would then execute the hidden LNK file.
T1210::[FIN7] has exploited ZeroLogon (CVE-2020-1472) against vulnerable domain controllers.
T1218.005::[FIN7] has used mshta.exe to execute VBScript to execute malicious code on victim systems.
T1486::[FIN7] has encrypted virtual disk volumes on ESXi servers using a version of Darkside ransomware.
T1497.002::[FIN7] used images embedded into document lures that only activate the payload when a user double clicks to avoid sandboxes.
T1543.003::[FIN7] created new Windows services and added them to the startup directories for persistence.
T1546.011::[FIN7] has used application shim databases for persistence.
T1547.001::[FIN7] malware has created Registry Run and RunOnce keys to establish persistence, and has also added items to the Startup folder.

T1553.002::[FIN7] has signed [Carbanak] payloads with legally purchased code signing certificates. [FIN7] has also digitally signed their phishing documents, backdoors and other staging tools to bypass security controls.
T1558.003::[FIN7] has used Kerberoasting for credential access and to enable lateral movement.
T1559.002::[FIN7] spear phishing campaigns have included malicious Word documents with DDE execution.
T1566.001::[FIN7] sent spearphishing emails with either malicious Microsoft Documents or RTF files attached.
T1566.002::[FIN7] has conducted broad phishing campaigns using malicious links.
T1567.002::[FIN7] has exfiltrated stolen data to the MEGA file sharing site.
T1571::[FIN7] has used port-protocol mismatches on ports such as 53, 80, 443, and 8080 during C2.
T1583.001::[FIN7] has registered look-alike domains for use in phishing campaigns.
T1587.001::[FIN7] has developed malware for use in operations, including the creation of infected removable media.

description: [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) is a financially-motivated threat group that has been active since 2013 primarily targeting the U.S. retail, restaurant, and hospitality sectors, often using point-of-sale malware. A portion of [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) was run out of a front company called Combi Security. Since 2020 [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) shifted operations to a big game hunting (BGH) approach including use of [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) ransomware and their own Ransomware as a Service (RaaS), Darkside. [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) may be linked to the [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) Group, but there appears to be several groups using [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) malware and are therefore tracked separately.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 March 2017)(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)(Citation: FireEye CARBANAK June 2017)(Citation: FireEye FIN7 Aug 2018)(Citation: CrowdStrike Carbon Spider August 2021)
